content:
Diagnosis:	Locally advanced hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma

Staging:	T2N1M0 (AJCC 8th edition)
	P16 negative, PDL1 CPS 35

Treatment:	Completed induction TPF chemotherapy March 2024
	Current - concurrent cisplatin-radiotherapy

Current Situation:	Week 4 of radiotherapy

I reviewed [redacted name] today during radiotherapy. He has completed 4 weeks of treatment, receiving 44Gy of the planned 70Gy in 35 fractions. He received cycle 1 cisplatin (100mg/m2) on day 1, but developed grade 3 acute kidney injury with creatinine rising to 198. This has now improved with supportive care to 132, but remains above baseline.

He has grade 2 radiation-induced mucositis requiring regular soluble morphine and nutritional supplements. His weight has dropped by 4kg despite dietetic support. He remains PS 1 and motivated to continue treatment.

After discussion with [redacted name] and the wider team, we will switch from high-dose cisplatin to weekly carboplatin AUC 1.5 for the remaining 3 weeks of treatment. This offers a better safety profile given his demonstrated cisplatin toxicity.

He will continue daily radiotherapy as planned. I have arranged weekly blood tests including renal function and magnesium. He will be reviewed twice weekly in the combined radiotherapy clinic. I have also arranged a PET-CT for 12 weeks after treatment completion to assess response.

Switching from high-dose cisplatin to weekly carboplatin AUC 1.5 due to renal toxicity

Creatinine improved to 132 but remains above baseline

status_updates.value: Locally advanced hypopharyngeal cancer receiving chemoradiotherapy. Treatment modification required due to cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity
Grade 3 acute kidney injury from cisplatin, grade 2 radiation mucositis
Switching to weekly carboplatin AUC 1.5 for remaining 3 weeks of concurrent chemoradiotherapy
PET-CT arranged for 12 weeks post-treatment completion
Twice weekly reviews in combined radiotherapy clinic with weekly blood tests
